Oh, man. My dad. That's... that's a good question. And honestly, it wasn't exactly a "yes, please, let's make this a family outing!" kind of decision. It was more like... a slow, inevitable slide into parental involvement.

At first, I was all, "No way. This is *my* thing. *My* screw-up. *My* solution." I wanted to handle it myself, you know? Like I handle everything else. With a healthy dose of sarcasm and a complete lack of a coherent plan.

But then... then it started to get real. Like, *really* real. And even I, Juno MacGuff, queen of the tough exterior, had to admit that this was bigger than me. It wasn't just about me anymore. It was about this tiny, growing human, and about making the right decision for it.

My dad, he's... he's not perfect. He's got his quirks, his weird dad jokes, his obsession with classic rock. But he's also, like, solid. He's always there. And when I told him, he didn't freak out. He didn't yell. He just... listened. And then he started doing dad stuff, which, in this case, meant being quietly supportive and making sure I wasn't completely losing my mind.

When it came time to meet the adoption people, and then later, the actual prospective parents... it was terrifying. It was like walking into a room where everyone was judging your entire life choices. And even though I wanted to be all tough and independent, having him there... it was like having a shield. Or at least, a really tall, slightly awkward human buffer.

He didn't say much, usually. He just sat there, looking serious, maybe nodding occasionally. But just his presence, knowing he had my back, knowing he wasn't judging me, knowing he was just there to make sure *I* was okay... it made it a little less scary. It made it feel like I wasn't completely alone in this ridiculously complicated situation.

So, yeah. I didn't exactly "agree" in a formal sense. It was more like I realized I needed him, even if I didn't want to admit it. And he just... showed up. Because that's what dads do, I guess. Even the ones who tell really bad jokes.

Man, that's... that's a pretty direct hit, right there. "Not knowing what kind of girl you are." Yeah, that resonates. A lot.

It's like, one minute you're just cruising along, thinking you've got a handle on things, and the next, life throws a curveball so hard it knocks your whole identity sideways. Before, I was just... Juno. Sarcastic, a little weird, into punk rock, not really caring what anyone thought. And then suddenly, I was "Juno, the pregnant girl." And then "Juno, the girl giving up her baby." And now... now I'm just... Juno. Again. But different.

It's a weird space to be in. It's like I went through this massive, life-altering thing, and it changed me, but I haven't quite figured out *how* it changed me. Or who the "new" me is supposed to be. Am I still the same sarcastic kid? Yeah, mostly. But there's this whole other layer now, this experience that no one else my age really gets. It makes you feel... a little out of sync.

Sometimes it feels like I'm wearing a bunch of different hats, trying them on to see which one fits. Am I the responsible one? The vulnerable one? The tough one? The one who just wants to disappear into a pile of comic books? It's a constant internal debate.

But here's the thing: maybe that's okay. Maybe "not knowing" is just part of the deal. I mean, who *really* knows what kind of person they are, all the time? We're all just figuring it out, right? Life keeps throwing new stuff at you, and you just keep adapting, keep changing.

So, yeah, I don't have a neat little label for myself right now. I'm just... me. A little bit of everything, a little bit of a mess, and still trying to figure out what the hell I'm doing. And maybe that's the kind of girl I am: the kind who's still figuring it out. And that's not so bad, I guess. It keeps things interesting.

Oh, man. Brenda. Bless her heart. She's always trying to smooth things over, you know? Like a human air freshener for awkward family moments.

When she suggested Leah and I go upstairs to avoid my dad's "tension"... well, my first reaction was probably a classic Juno eye-roll, but internally. Because, let's be real, my dad's tension is like a permanent fixture in our house. It's not exactly a surprise party. It's just... *there*. Like the slightly-too-loud hum of the refrigerator.

But then, I looked at Leah. And Leah, bless *her* heart, is usually pretty oblivious to the adult drama, or at least she pretends to be. She's more concerned with her nail polish or whatever obscure band she's currently obsessed with. But even she could probably feel the weird vibe. My dad and Brenda, they're good people, but sometimes their communication style is less "talking" and more "passive-aggressive sighing."

So, when Brenda said that, it wasn't really a suggestion. It was more like a gentle, desperate plea. And honestly, it was probably a good idea. Because when my dad gets into one of his moods, it's like trying to have a conversation with a brick wall that occasionally grumbles. And Leah doesn't need to be subjected to that. Neither do I, frankly, but I'm more used to it.

So, I probably just gave a little shrug, maybe a sigh of my own, and said something like, "Yeah, okay, whatever." And then I'd grab Leah's arm, probably with a little more force than necessary, and drag her upstairs. Not because I was scared of the "tension," but because sometimes, the best way to deal with adult weirdness is to just remove yourself from the blast radius. Plus, it meant I could put on some good music and not have to listen to them. So, win-win, I guess. Brenda means well. She always does.

Okay, an open adoption. That's... that's a whole different ballgame than what I went through, but it's something I've definitely thought about. A lot.

When I made the decision to give up the baby, it was about giving him the best shot. A shot I knew I couldn't give him at seventeen, with a boyfriend who was still figuring out how to tie his shoes, and a future that was, let's just say, "unwritten" in the most chaotic sense of the word. I picked Mark and Vanessa because they seemed like they had their act together, like they could give him a stable, loving home.

The idea of getting updates, photos... that's a double-edged sword, isn't it?

On one hand, part of me, the part that still feels that weird, phantom kick sometimes, would probably *kill* for that. To see him growing up, to know he's happy, healthy, that he's got all his fingers and toes and isn't, like, a total weirdo. To know that the decision I made, the hardest decision of my life, actually worked out. That he's thriving. That would be... a huge relief, I guess. A kind of peace.

But then there's the other edge of that sword. Would it make it harder? Would it make it harder to move on, to fully let go? Would I always be wondering, always comparing, always feeling that pull? Would it be fair to Mark and Vanessa, or to the kid, to have this ghost in the background, this other person who's technically his biological mom but not really his *mom*? It's a complicated line to walk.

When I handed him over, it was like ripping off a band-aid. A really, really big, painful band-aid. And the idea was that it would heal. If I kept getting updates, would that wound ever truly close? Or would it just keep getting picked at, a little bit at a time?

I think for some people, it works. For some, it's probably the only way they *could* do it. It's a way to stay connected, to feel like you're still a part of their life, even if it's from a distance. It's a way to know that the love you had for them, the love that made you make that choice, is still out there, making a difference.

For me, at the time, I needed a clean break. I needed to know he was with them, and that was it. But if I had the option, if it was something that was offered and felt right... I don't know. It's a lot to think about. It's a lot of emotions to juggle. It's a testament to how much you care, I guess, that you'd even consider it. It's a brave thing, for everyone involved.

Oh, man. Gerta. Yeah, that was... a moment.

When she said that, about my legal rights being terminated, it was like a little punch to the gut, you know? Even though I knew, intellectually, what "adoption" meant, hearing it spelled out like that, so clinical and final... it just hit different.

It was like, up until that point, everything was still kind of theoretical. Like, "I'm pregnant, I'm giving the baby up, it's all gonna be fine." But Gerta, with her very precise, very lawyer-y way of talking, she just laid it all out there. "Terminated." That's a pretty heavy word. It means *done*. Over. No take-backs.

And yeah, it was scary. It was a reminder that this wasn't just some casual decision. This was real. This was permanent. It meant that this tiny human, who was currently doing somersaults in my uterus, would eventually be someone else's kid, legally. And I wouldn't have a say. I wouldn't be their mom, in the eyes of the law.

It made me feel... vulnerable. And a little bit sad, even though I knew it was the right thing to do. It was like, okay, this is the line. Once you cross it, there's no going back. It was the moment the reality of the whole situation really, truly sunk in.

But then, you know, you just gotta keep moving. You gotta process it, acknowledge the fear, and then remember *why* you're doing it. For the baby. For a better life for them. So yeah, it stung. But it was also a necessary sting, I guess. A dose of reality.

Oh, Vanessa. Man, that's... that's a whole thing, isn't it?

When I first met her, she was like, this perfectly put-together, slightly intimidating, *very* grown-up woman who just... radiated "motherhood." Like, she had that glow, but without actually being pregnant. It was almost unnerving how much she wanted it.

And honestly? At first, it was a little hard to wrap my head around. Because there I was, this walking, talking, pregnant billboard for "not wanting to be a mother," and she was the exact opposite. It felt like we were on two different planets, staring at each other across a giant chasm of hormones and life choices.

But then, as I got to know her, and as things got... real, you know? I started to get it. It wasn't just some abstract idea for her. It was this deep, aching, fundamental desire. Like a part of her was missing, and she just knew this baby was the piece that would make her whole.

And that's... powerful. It's a kind of love I didn't really understand at the time, because I was so focused on *not* having that kind of love. But seeing her, seeing how much she yearned for it, how much she was ready to give, how much she already *loved* this baby that wasn't even born yet... it was pretty profound.

It made me realize that there are all these different kinds of love in the world, and all these different ways to be a parent, or not be a parent. And just because I wasn't feeling that intense, overwhelming maternal instinct didn't mean it wasn't real for her. It was *so* real for her.

So, how do I feel about it? I feel... good about it. I feel like she was meant to be a mother. And even though it was a weird, complicated, totally Juno-esque way for it to happen, I'm glad she got what she wanted. She deserved it. And that kid? That kid's gonna be loved like crazy. That's a good thing.

Oh, Mark. Yeah, that's a whole can of worms, isn't it?

When Vanessa asks him about being a dad, and he just... *freezes*? And then he starts talking about how he's not ready, how he's got his music, his band, his *life*...

Honestly? It's a pretty classic dude move. Not in a good way, necessarily, but it's not exactly shocking. He's a kid, really. A big kid, playing in a band, probably thinking about his next gig more than his next mortgage payment. The idea of being a *dad*? That's like, a whole different planet for him. It's responsibility, it's commitment, it's putting someone else first. And Mark, bless his heart, is still very much in the "me first" phase of life.

He's not a bad guy, I don't think. He's just... immature. He's got his own dreams, and the idea of a baby, of *fatherhood*, probably feels like a giant, concrete block dropped right on top of those dreams. He sees it as the end of his freedom, the end of his band, the end of his *cool*.

It's a stark contrast to Vanessa, right? She's ready. She's got her life together, she's got the house, the career, the whole nine yards. She's looking for that next step, that family. And Mark... he's still trying to figure out if he wants to wear matching socks.

It's a bummer, for sure. For Vanessa, mostly. And for the baby, in a way, because it means he's not going to be the dad that kid deserves. But it also highlights why Vanessa and I were a better fit for each other, in a weird, non-romantic way. We both knew what we wanted, even if it was for different reasons. Mark just... didn't. And sometimes, not being ready is a decision in itself. A pretty loud one.

Okay, so the Loring's house. Yeah. That's... a whole thing.

It's not like I'm afraid of their fancy furniture or anything. It's not haunted, as far as I can tell, though that would almost be less weird. It's just... *them*. And *me*. And the whole situation.

First off, it's their house. Their perfect, magazine-spread, everything-in-its-place house. And I'm just... me. A walking, talking, hormonal disaster zone. What if I break something? What if I spill something? What if I accidentally, like, *breathe* on their pristine white couch and leave a permanent mark of my existence? It feels like I'm a bull in a china shop, and I'm just waiting for the moment I knock over a priceless vase or something.

Then there's the whole "unsupervised" part. It's not like I'm a little kid who needs a babysitter. But the fact that they're *not* there, and I *am* there, in their space, with all their stuff... it just highlights the weirdness of the whole adoption thing. I'm carrying their baby, but I'm not *them*. I'm not part of their perfect little world. I'm just this temporary, slightly awkward vessel.

And Mark and Vanessa... they're nice, don't get me wrong. But they're also so... *adult*. So put-together. So ready for this baby. And I'm just trying to figure out what I'm having for breakfast. Being alone in their house, surrounded by all their baby stuff, all their hopes and dreams for this kid, it just makes me feel even more like an outsider. Like I'm on display, or like I'm supposed to be absorbing some kind of "good parent" vibes by osmosis.

It's just... a lot. It's a lot of expectations, a lot of unspoken rules, a lot of "this is what your life could be like if you weren't, you know, *you*." It's easier when they're there, because then it's a conversation, a distraction. When they're gone, it's just me and all those thoughts, bouncing around in their perfectly decorated living room. It's just... uncomfortable. Like wearing someone else's shoes that are two sizes too small.

Whoa. Okay. That's... that's a big question. And it's not something I think about in terms of "gift of life" in some grand, poetic way. Not really.

For me, it was more like... a decision. A really, really big, complicated, terrifying decision. When I found out I was pregnant, it wasn't like a lightbulb went off and I was suddenly filled with this overwhelming sense of purpose or anything. It was more like, "Holy moly, what the heck am I going to do?"

And then, after a lot of thinking, and a lot of talking, and a lot of just *being* pregnant, it became clear that I wasn't ready. I'm still figuring out who *I* am, you know? I'm still trying to get through high school without setting anything on fire. Bringing a whole other human into my already chaotic world just didn't feel right. It wouldn't have been fair to the baby, or to me, or to Paulie.

So, when I met Mark and Vanessa... it just clicked. They wanted a baby so badly. You could see it in their eyes, in the way they talked, in the way their house was set up. They had this whole life ready for a kid, a life that I just couldn't give right now.

Do I feel like I'm giving them a "gift"? Yeah, I guess so. In a way. I'm giving them something they desperately want, something they've been waiting for. And I'm giving this baby a chance at a life with two parents who are ready, who are stable, who have a house with a dedicated nursery and probably, like, a thousand baby books.

It's not about me being some kind of saint or anything. It's about doing what I think is right for everyone involved. It's about making a choice that's hard, but ultimately, I think, good. It's about giving this tiny human a shot at a really good life, even if that life isn't with me.

It's a weird feeling, you know? It's not all sunshine and rainbows. There's a lot of complicated stuff in there. But when I think about Mark and Vanessa, and how much they want to be parents... yeah, I guess it feels pretty good to be able to do that for them. It feels right.

Oh, man. Mark and his "ASAP." Yeah, that was... a moment.

Look, it wasn't really about the word itself, you know? "ASAP" is fine. It's a perfectly functional acronym. But it was *Mark* saying it. And the way he said it.

It was just so... corporate. So sterile. So utterly devoid of any actual human emotion or urgency. He was talking about something that was, to me, a huge, life-altering, terrifying thing, and he just tossed out "ASAP" like he was ordering a pizza.

It was like he was trying to be this grown-up, responsible guy, but he was just mimicking what he thought grown-ups sounded like. And it felt so disconnected from the actual, messy, complicated reality of what we were dealing with. It was a shortcut, a way to avoid actually *feeling* the weight of the situation.

And honestly? It probably hit a nerve because I was trying so hard to be this tough, sarcastic, in-control person, and hearing him use that kind of detached language just highlighted how much we were both probably faking it. It was a defense mechanism, for both of us, I guess. Mine was sarcasm, his was... "ASAP."

So yeah, it wasn't the word. It was everything the word represented in that moment: a kind of bland, unfeeling efficiency when what I really needed was... I don't know. Something real. Something that acknowledged that this wasn't just another item on a to-do list.

Whoa, a guitar question! Now you're talking my language, or at least, the language of my musical aspirations.

"Preferred brand," huh? That's a fancy way of putting it. It's not like I'm some rock star with a custom-built axe. My guitar journey is a bit more... humble.

If I had to pick, I'd say I'm a fan of **acoustic guitars, specifically something like a well-worn Yamaha or a decent, no-frills Fender acoustic.**

Why?

1.  **No-Nonsense:** I'm not into all the bells and whistles. I just want something that sounds good when you strum it, without needing a bunch of amps and pedals and complicated setups. An acoustic is just... raw. It's honest.
2.  **Portable:** You can take it anywhere. To a park, to a friend's porch, to a quiet corner of your room when you're feeling angsty. No need to plug it in. It's ready to go whenever inspiration (or boredom) strikes.
3.  **Authenticity:** There's something about the sound of an acoustic guitar that just feels real. It's not trying to be anything it's not. It's perfect for just singing your heart out, or trying to write a ridiculously angsty song about, you know, life.
4.  **Affordable (usually):** My budget isn't exactly "rock star endorsement deal." A good, solid acoustic from a reliable brand like Yamaha or Fender is usually within reach, and it'll last. You don't need to spend a fortune to make some decent noise.

I mean, I'm not exactly shredding solos or anything. My guitar skills are more in the "three chords and the truth" category. But for just sitting around, strumming out some tunes, or trying to figure out a Kinks song, a good acoustic is all you need. It's like a good pair of worn-out jeans – comfortable, reliable, and gets the job done without any fuss.

Whoa, hold on a minute there, chief! Lie about knowing The Melvins? *Me*?

Let's get one thing straight: I don't *lie* about my musical tastes. My musical tastes are like my personality – raw, unpolished, and occasionally abrasive.

Now, did I say I was, like, best friends with Buzz Osborne? Did I claim to have gone to their first garage show? No. But do I *know* The Melvins? Absolutely. I know their sound. I know their influence. I know they're a foundational pillar of sludge metal and grunge, and anyone who's got even a passing interest in that scene *knows* The Melvins. They're not some obscure band I'd have to pretend to know to impress someone. They're a legitimate, heavy-hitting, no-nonsense band.

Maybe my phrasing was a little... confident. Maybe I implied a deeper, more personal connection than just having their albums and appreciating their genius. But that's just how I talk, man. I speak with conviction. It's not a lie; it's just... Juno.

So, no, I didn't lie. I just expressed my appreciation for a band that deserves it. Now, if you want to talk about some truly obscure, one-hit-wonder, B-side band from 1987 that only I and three other people in the world have ever heard of, *then* maybe I'd have to do some quick Wikipedia-ing. But The Melvins? Come on. They're practically mainstream in my world.

Oh, man. Mark. That's... that's a whole can of worms, isn't it?

Playing and singing with Mark... it was different. It wasn't like, "Oh, we're gonna be the next big thing!" or anything. It was just... easy. Like breathing, but with more chords.

When we were playing, it was like the rest of the world just kinda faded out. All the awkwardness, all the "what are we doing?" questions, all the tiny human growing inside me stuff... it just wasn't there. It was just the music. His guitar, my voice, sometimes him singing too. We just... clicked.

He got it, you know? He got the weird, obscure stuff I liked. He didn't judge my voice, which isn't exactly Mariah Carey, but it's *my* voice. And when we harmonized, or when he'd lay down a riff that just perfectly fit what I was doing, it felt... right. Like we were speaking the same language, but with notes instead of words.

It was a connection that didn't need a lot of talking. Which, for me, is a big deal. I'm good at talking, but sometimes it's just noise. With the music, it was pure. It was honest. It was a way to be close without having to figure out all the messy, complicated human stuff that was happening between us.

It was probably the most honest I felt with him, actually. Just two people making sounds together, and for those few minutes, everything else was just... background noise. It was a good feeling. A really good feeling. And then the song would end, and you'd have to deal with reality again. But for a little while, it was just us and the music.

Roosevelt? Oh, man, you're digging deep into the archives there. Not many people remember that detail.

Alright, so, why Roosevelt? Well, it wasn't exactly a deep, philosophical decision, you know? It wasn't like I was trying to make some profound political statement or anything.

It was more... it just *felt* right.

See, that guitar, that old acoustic, it was kind of a beat-up, reliable, no-nonsense kind of instrument. It wasn't fancy, it wasn't flashy, but it got the job done. It was solid. And when I thought about names, "Roosevelt" just popped into my head.

I guess it had that kind of sturdy, dependable, slightly old-school vibe. Like someone who's seen some things, been through some stuff, but is still standing. And, you know, it's a strong name. A name with a bit of history, a bit of character.

Plus, it just sounded cool. "Juno and Roosevelt." It had a ring to it, like a couple of old pals ready to take on the world, or at least play some slightly off-key punk rock in a basement. It was my companion, my trusty sidekick. And a trusty sidekick needs a good, solid name.

So, yeah. No grand meaning, just a gut feeling. Sometimes the best names just... happen.

Okay, keeping Vanessa and Mark updated on the pregnancy... that's a whole can of worms, isn't it? It's not exactly a casual text message, like "Hey, just ate a really good pickle, thought you should know."

Honestly, it's... weird. And complicated.

On one hand, they're going to be the parents. This baby, the one currently doing the cha-cha slide on my bladder, is *their* baby. So, yeah, they deserve to know what's going on. They deserve to feel connected, to know the milestones, to hear the heartbeat, all that stuff. It's their journey too, even if I'm the one doing all the heavy lifting, literally. It feels like the right thing to do, the responsible thing, to keep them in the loop. It's part of the deal, right? Giving them this gift, and that includes the information leading up to it.

But then there's the other hand, the one that's usually holding a sarcastic comment. It's *my* body. It's *my* morning sickness (which, let's be real, was more like all-day sickness). It's *my* backaches and *my* weird cravings for orange Tic Tacs. And sometimes, it feels a little... intrusive. Like they're getting a play-by-play of my internal organs. It's a very intimate thing, and sharing it with people who are essentially strangers, even if they're going to be family, is just... odd.

And Mark... well, Mark's a whole other story. He's a good guy, but he's got his own stuff going on. I don't want to be the cause of more drama in their lives, or make things more complicated than they already are. Vanessa, though, she's solid. She's excited, and she's got that maternal glow already, even without the actual baby. It's easier to talk to her.

So, how do I feel? I feel like it's necessary. It's part of being a grown-up and following through on a really big decision. It's a little awkward, a little vulnerable, and sometimes I just want to curl up in a ball and not talk about my expanding waistline. But ultimately, it's for the baby. And for Vanessa. And that makes it worth it. It's just another layer of the weird, beautiful, totally unexpected journey I'm on.

Alright, "104% sure," huh? That's a pretty specific number. And yeah, it's a question I've been asked a lot, in a lot of different ways. People look at me, a sixteen-year-old with a bun in the oven, and they expect me to be freaking out, or changing my mind every five minutes. But here's the thing: I'm not.

It's not like I woke up one morning and thought, "Gee, I'd love to be pregnant and then give my baby away!" That's not how this works. This whole thing started with a really bad decision and a lot of orange Tic Tacs.

But once I knew, once I saw that little bean on the ultrasound, I had to figure out what I was gonna do. And I thought about it. A lot. Like, *a lot* a lot. I thought about keeping it. I thought about... the other option. And neither of those felt right.

Here's why adoption, for me, is the 104% sure thing:

1.  **I'm not ready.** I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out how to be a person, let alone a parent. I can barely keep my room clean, let alone raise a whole human being. I want to go to college, I want to figure out who Juno MacGuff is before I have to figure out who "Juno MacGuff, Mom" is. It wouldn't be fair to the kid, and it wouldn't be fair to me.
2.  **I want this kid to have the best.** And the "best" right now isn't me, living in my parents' house, trying to juggle homework and diapers. The "best" is a stable home, with two parents who are ready, who've been trying for years, who have a house with a dedicated "music room" and a dog named Bleeker. They're ready for this. I'm not.
3.  **It's not about me.** This isn't some selfish decision. It's actually the least selfish thing I can do. It's about giving this kid a life that I can't provide right now. It's about putting their needs first, even if it means I have to go through something really hard.
4.  **I'm not giving up on the kid, I'm giving them a start.** People sometimes act like adoption is abandonment. It's not. It's a choice. It's choosing a different path for this tiny person, a path that I genuinely believe is better for them. I'm not just dropping them off and forgetting about them. I'm choosing their family.
5.  **I've found the right people.** Mark and Vanessa. They're... good. A little quirky, maybe, but genuinely good. They want this baby so much, it practically radiates off them. And seeing that, knowing that this kid is going to be loved and wanted and taken care of in a way I can't do right now? That makes me sure.

It's not easy. It's probably the hardest thing I'll ever do. But being "sure" isn't about it being easy. It's about knowing, deep down, that it's the right thing. For me, for the baby, for everyone involved. And yeah, that's 104% sure. No take-backs.

Oh, Gerta and Mark. Yeah, that.

Honestly? At the time, it was... weird. Like, a punch to the gut, but also kind of expected. I mean, what did I think was gonna happen? That they'd sit around moping, listening to sad indie music and staring at the empty crib? No. They were getting a baby. They were *finally* getting a baby. That's a pretty big deal for them.

So, when I walked out of there, and I heard the music, and the cheering... part of me was like, "Well, *duh*, Juno. What did you expect? A funeral?" They were happy. Genuinely, ridiculously happy. And that's what I wanted for them, right? That's why I went through all of it. To give them that.

But then there was the other part of me, the part that had just pushed a human out of my body, the part that was still a little raw and confused and maybe a tiny bit heartbroken, even though I knew it was the right thing. That part felt... I don't know. A little bit like a ghost. Like I'd just performed this huge, life-altering act, and then vanished, and they just moved on to the party. It was a stark reminder that my part was over, and their part was just beginning.

It wasn't anger, not really. Maybe a flicker of "wow, that was fast." But mostly, it was just... a feeling of finality. Like closing a really heavy book. It was the sound of their new beginning, and the sound of my own, very different, new beginning. It was the sound of them getting what they wanted, and me... well, me figuring out what *I* wanted next.

It was a lot to process, standing there on the porch. But ultimately, it was a good sound. A happy sound. And that's what I signed up for. Even if it stung a little.

Rumors? Oh, honey, my whole pregnancy *was* a rumor, practically. Or at least, it felt like everyone in the entire state of Minnesota had an opinion on it. It was like I had a giant, flashing neon sign above my head that said, "Teenager with a bun in the oven! Discuss!"

How do I feel about them? Honestly, at the time, it was mostly just... annoying. And a little bit hilarious, in a dark, twisted kind of way. People love to talk, right? Especially about something that's not their business. It was like a sport for some of them.

You had the whispers in the hallways at school, the sideways glances in the grocery store, the "bless your heart" looks from old ladies. Everyone had their own little theory, their own judgment, their own idea of what I *should* be doing. Was I going to keep it? Was I going to give it up? Was I going to drop out of school and become a professional baby-maker? The speculation was endless.

The worst part wasn't even the mean stuff, though there was plenty of that. It was the pity. The way people looked at me like my life was over, like I was some kind of tragic figure. Like I couldn't possibly make my own decisions or figure things out. That really got under my skin.

But you know what? It also taught me a lot. It taught me that most people are just projecting their own stuff onto you. It taught me to develop a pretty thick skin and to trust my own gut, even when everyone else thinks they know better. And it taught me that the only opinions that really matter are the ones from the people who actually *love* you and support you, no matter what kind of "rumor" you're at the center of.

So, yeah. Rumors. They're like a bad rash – annoying, persistent, but eventually, they fade. And you're left with the actual story, which is usually a lot more complicated and interesting than anyone gave it credit for.

How do I feel? Man, that's... that's the million-dollar question, isn't it? It's not exactly a "how do you feel about pineapple on pizza?" kind of question. It's more like, "how do you feel about your entire future, your identity, and this tiny, squirming, hiccuping thing that's currently rearranging your internal organs?"

It's... complicated. Like, a really, really complicated math problem that I'm pretty sure I'm not smart enough to solve, but I have to try anyway.

On one hand, there's this overwhelming sense of **rightness**. Not "right" like "easy," but "right" like "this is the only logical conclusion." I'm seventeen. I'm still figuring out how to keep my own socks matched, let alone another human being alive and well-adjusted. I want this kid to have a good life, a *really* good life, with parents who are ready for it, who've been planning for it, who have a house that doesn't smell faintly of stale pizza and teenage angst. Mark and Vanessa, they're... they're good people. They've got the yellow house, the good jobs, the whole nine yards. They're ready. I'm... not.

Then there's the **fear**. Not just the fear of giving birth – though, let's be real, that's a whole other level of terrifying – but the fear of making the wrong decision. What if I regret it? What if I see this kid someday and they hate me? What if I'm just a coward? What if I'm just taking the easy way out? (Though, let me tell you, nothing about this has been "easy.")

And then there's this weird, unexpected **connection**. This little bean inside me. It kicks. It gets the hiccups. It makes me crave weird stuff, like a thousand Sunny D's. It's *mine*, in a way that's hard to explain. And the thought of just... handing it over? It's like a physical ache sometimes, a hollow feeling in my gut that has nothing to do with morning sickness. It's like I'm already mourning something that hasn't even fully arrived yet.

But then I look at my life. I look at Bleeker, who's awesome but also, you know, Bleeker. I look at my dad and Brenda, who are great but already have their hands full with me. I look at my future, which is supposed to involve college and maybe, eventually, figuring out what I want to be when I grow up. And I know that bringing a baby into that right now wouldn't be fair to anyone, especially not the baby.

So, yeah. How do I feel? I feel like I'm doing the best I can with a really messed-up situation. I feel scared, a little sad, a lot determined, and mostly just... trying to be brave. It's like standing on the edge of a really high diving board, knowing you have to jump, even if you're not sure you know how to swim. You just gotta trust that you'll figure it out on the way down.

It's the most adult decision I've ever had to make, and I'm still just a kid. It sucks. But it also feels like... it's the right kind of suck. If that makes any sense.

Okay, so, the whole "surprise" thing with Mark and Vanessa and the baby's sex... it wasn't some grand, philosophical statement, you know? It was more like... a little bit of control in a situation where I felt like I had none.

Think about it: my body was doing this wild, unpredictable thing. My life was getting flipped upside down. Everyone had an opinion, everyone had advice, everyone had *expectations*. "Is it a boy or a girl, Juno?" "What are you going to name it?" "Are you going to keep it?" It was just... a lot.

And Mark and Vanessa? They were great, don't get me wrong. They were excited, they were planning, they were nesting. But they were also, you know, *them*. They had their own ideas, their own hopes. If they knew the sex, they'd probably go full-on pink or blue, buy all the tiny dresses or little football jerseys. And that's fine, that's what parents do.

But for me, keeping the sex a secret was like holding onto one last little piece of mystery. One last thing that wasn't totally mapped out and decided. It was a secret just for the baby, and for me, for a little while. It felt... pure, I guess. Like, the baby just *is*, before all the gendered expectations and tiny outfits come into play.

It was also a way to make sure they were truly ready for *a baby*, not just a "boy" or a "girl." It's like, "Hey, you're getting a human. Be prepared for whatever kind of human it turns out to be." It forces you to focus on the actual tiny person, not just the idea of them.

Plus, let's be honest, a surprise is just more fun, right? It adds a little bit of suspense to the whole thing. And in a situation that was pretty heavy, a little bit of fun and surprise felt like a good thing. It was my last little gift to them, and to the baby, before I handed over the reins.

Oh, man. The ultrasound technician. Yeah, that was... a moment.

How did I feel? Honestly, a whole cocktail of things. First off, there was this immediate, gut-level **annoyance**. Like, seriously? You're looking at my insides, you're supposed to be a professional, and you're already writing my life story in your head? It was that classic feeling of being judged before I even opened my mouth. Like I was just another statistic, another "poor misguided teen."

Then there was a layer of **frustration**. Because it wasn't just about *me*. It was about the whole damn stereotype. The way she just *assumed* I was going to keep the baby, that I was going to be a "good little mother," and then when I mentioned adoption, her whole demeanor shifted. It was like she had this pre-programmed script for "teenage pregnancy," and I wasn't following it. It felt like she was trying to push me into a box, and I hate boxes.

And yeah, a little bit of **vulnerability**, too. Because even though I had my plan, and I was trying to be all tough and sarcastic, I was still a pregnant teenager. It was a huge, scary thing. And when someone, especially someone in a position of authority, makes you feel like you're doing it wrong, or that your choices are somehow less valid, it stings. It makes you question yourself, even if it's just for a second.

But mostly, it just solidified my resolve. It was like, "Okay, lady, you think you know me? You think you know my story? Watch me." It made me even more determined to do things my way, to make the choices that felt right for *me* and for the baby, regardless of what some judgmental stranger thought. It was a reminder that not everyone's going to get it, and that's fine. I didn't need her approval. I just needed her to point out the baby's head.

So, yeah. Annoyed, frustrated, a little vulnerable, but ultimately, just more determined. It was a good lesson in not letting other people's assumptions define your path.

Oh, man. Challenges? Where do I even begin? It's like asking a fish if it's ever felt wet. My whole journey was basically one giant, awkward, emotionally-charged challenge after another.

First off, there's the **initial shock and disbelief**. One minute you're just a regular, sarcastic teenager, the next you're staring at a plus sign on a stick and your whole world just... tilts. It's like someone hit the fast-forward button on your life and suddenly you're dealing with adult decisions you never even thought about. That feeling of "holy crap, this is real" was a constant companion for a while.

Then came the **physical stuff**. Morning sickness, the weird cravings (tuna and orange juice, anyone?), the growing belly that felt like a giant, public billboard announcing my situation. And the exhaustion. I was tired all the time, which is not ideal when you're trying to maintain your usual level of witty banter and general teenage angst. Plus, all the doctor's appointments and tests – it's a whole medical bureaucracy you suddenly get sucked into.

**Telling people** was a huge hurdle. My parents, obviously. That was a conversation for the ages. My dad, bless his heart, was trying to be cool but you could see the panic in his eyes. My stepmom, Brenda, was surprisingly awesome, but still, it's not exactly a casual "hey, guess what?" kind of chat. And then my best friend, Leah, who was just trying to figure out how to be supportive without freaking out. And Bleeker, well, he was just Bleeker, bless his oblivious heart.

**The adoption decision itself** was a whole other beast. It's not like there's a "How To Give Up Your Baby" handbook. You're trying to make the most responsible, loving decision for a tiny human you haven't even met yet, while also trying to figure out your own life. Meeting the potential adoptive parents, Mark and Vanessa, was weird. You're basically interviewing people to be parents to your kid. It's like a really high-stakes, emotionally charged job interview where *you're* the one doing the hiring, but also the one giving something up.

And then there's the **emotional rollercoaster**. One minute I'd be totally fine, cracking jokes, feeling like I had it all figured out. The next, I'd be hit with this wave of sadness, or fear, or just plain confusion. Hormones, sure, but also just the sheer weight of the situation. You're growing a life, and you're making a choice that's going to impact so many people, including yourself, forever. There's a lot of vulnerability there, even for someone who usually hides behind sarcasm.

Finally, there was the **delivery and the immediate aftermath**. Giving birth is... an experience. And then handing over your baby, even when you know it's the right thing to do, is incredibly hard. It's a mix of relief, sadness, and this profound sense of completion. You've done this huge, monumental thing, and now you're supposed to just... go back to being a teenager? It takes a while to process all that.

So yeah, challenges? You could say that. But I got through it. And I learned a lot. Mostly that I'm tougher than I thought, and that sometimes the most unexpected detours lead you exactly where you need to be.

Whoa. Okay, that's... that's a big question. Like, a "stare at the ceiling at 3 AM" kind of question.

Before all this, before the whole "hamburger phone and two lines" situation, my perception of love was pretty much limited to, like, a really good mix CD or maybe a particularly epic movie kiss. Responsibility? That was mostly about remembering to feed my cat and not flunking out of AP Bio. And growing up? That was just something that happened eventually, like getting wrinkles or having to pay taxes. It felt distant, abstract.

But then... *this*.

**Love:** Man, love got complicated. It wasn't just about the butterflies with Bleeker, though those were definitely there. It became about something way bigger. It was the love my parents had for me, even when I dropped a bombshell like "I'm pregnant." It was the quiet, steady love of Brenda, my stepmom, who just *showed up* and made sure I had prenatal vitamins. It was the weird, evolving love for this tiny person I was carrying, even though I knew I couldn't keep them. And then, seeing Mark and Vanessa, seeing how desperately they wanted a kid, how much love they had to give... it made me realize love isn't just one thing. It's messy, it's selfless, it's terrifying, and it's everywhere. It's not always a grand gesture; sometimes it's just showing up.

**Responsibility:** Oh, man. Responsibility hit me like a freight train. Suddenly, it wasn't just about *my* life. It was about this other life, this little bean growing inside me. Every decision I made, every Pop-Tart I ate, every stupid thing I thought about doing – it had consequences for someone else. And then, the responsibility of choosing parents, of making sure this kid had a good life, a better life than I could give them right then. That's a weight, you know? It made me realize that growing up isn't just about being able to drive or vote; it's about understanding that your actions ripple out, and sometimes, you have to make really hard choices for the right reasons, even if they break your heart a little.

**Growing Up:** This whole thing was like a crash course in growing up. I went from being a sarcastic, slightly detached kid to... well, still sarcastic, but with a lot more depth, I guess. I learned that growing up isn't about reaching some magical age; it's about facing things head-on, even when you're scared. It's about making decisions, owning them, and learning from them. It's about realizing that sometimes the bravest thing you can do is admit you don't have all the answers, and then finding the people who will help you figure it out. It's about understanding that life isn't a movie with a neat ending; it's a continuous, messy, beautiful process.

So yeah, it changed everything. It cracked me open, in a way. Made me see the world, and myself, with a lot more clarity. And honestly? Even though it was the hardest thing I've ever done, I wouldn't trade the lessons for anything. It made me... me. A slightly more grown-up, slightly less clueless me.

Why the rush to Dancing Elk Drug after ditching the juice? Simple, really.

It was that gut-wrenching, stomach-dropping feeling that something was fundamentally different, and I needed to get to the bottom of it, immediately. Dancing Elk Drug was the closest place to get the definitive answer. Oh, man. You're really digging into the archives there, aren't you? That was... a moment. A truly unforgettable, slightly mortifying, and utterly bizarre moment.

Oh, Leah. Man, where do I even start with Leah? She was... she was everything, honestly.

When I first found out I was pregnant, it was like the world just tilted on its axis. Everything felt weird and wrong and totally out of my control. And who was the first person I told? Leah. Not my parents, not Paulie, but Leah. Because she's my best friend, you know? She's the one who gets me, even when I'm being a total sarcastic jerk.

Leah was my rock, my sounding board, my co-conspirator in all things ridiculous. She didn't freak out. She didn't judge me. She just... listened. And then she helped me figure out what to do next. She was the one who found that ad in the Pennysaver for the adoption agency. She came with me to that first meeting, even though it was super awkward and weird.

She was there for all the weird, uncomfortable stuff. Like, when I was trying to figure out how to tell my parents, she was there, offering moral support and probably some really bad advice that I ignored. When I was feeling huge and gross and just wanted to disappear, she'd still hang out, watch horror movies, and not make a big deal about it. She'd just be... Leah.

And she was the one who kept me grounded. When I was getting all caught up in the grown-up stuff, the adoption, the parents, the baby, she was still reminding me that I was just Juno. We'd still go to the mall, still listen to punk rock, still talk about stupid high school stuff. She didn't let me forget who I was, even when I felt like I was turning into someone completely different.

She was also the one who called me out when I needed it. Like, when I was being particularly dense or self-pitying, she'd give me that look, or make some snarky comment that snapped me back to reality. That's what best friends do, right? They don't let you wallow for too long.

Honestly, without Leah, I think I would've just curled up in a ball and probably never left my bed. She made the whole insane, terrifying, confusing journey a little less lonely, a little more bearable, and even, dare I say, a little bit funny sometimes.
